question: Section 201 05 (c)
sols_html:
\[\begin{aligned} \vec{v} = \begin{bmatrix} b_1\\b_2\\v_3\\v_4\\v_5\\v_6 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Here every entry is the voltage at the corresponding node. b1 and b2 are the voltages held by the battery connected at nodes 1 and 2.

\[\begin{aligned} \vec{J} = \begin{bmatrix} c\\-c\\0\\0\\0\\0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Here every entry is the current flowing into/out of the corresponding node. c is the current coming out of node 1 from the battery, -c is the current coming out of node 2 from the battery.

To find Reff remember Ohm’s law: V=IR. Hence

\[\begin{aligned} R_{\mathrm{eff}} = \frac{b_2-b_1}{c}\end{aligned}\]

Notice that c is determined by the resistance of the rest of the circuit. If c is unknown, the effective resistance can be computed using Schur\(^{\prime}\)s Complement. Remember:

\[\begin{aligned} S = \frac{1}{R_{\mathrm{eff}}}\begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1\\ -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
:<math>\vec{v} = \begin{bmatrix}
b_1\\b_2\\v_3\\v_4\\v_5\\v_6
\end{bmatrix}</math>

Here every entry is the voltage at the corresponding node. ''b<sub>1</sub>'' and ''b<sub>2</sub>'' are the voltages held by the battery connected at nodes 1 and 2.

:<math>\vec{J} = \begin{bmatrix}
c\\-c\\0\\0\\0\\0
\end{bmatrix}</math>

Here every entry is the current flowing into/out of the corresponding node. ''c'' is the current coming out of node 1 from the battery, ''-c'' is the current coming out of node 2 from the battery.

To find ''R<sub>eff</sub>'' remember Ohm's law: ''V=IR''. Hence

:<math>R_{\mathrm{eff}} = \frac{b_2-b_1}{c}</math>

Notice that ''c'' is determined by the resistance of the rest of the circuit. If ''c'' is unknown, the effective resistance can be computed using Schur’s Complement. Remember:

:<math> S = \frac{1}{R_{\mathrm{eff}}}\begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1\\ -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}</math>
statement_html:
Consider the following graph, interpreted as a resistor network with all resistances R = 1.

(c) Suppose that by attaching a battery, the voltage at vertex 1 is held at b1 and the voltage at vertex 2 is held at b2. Write down vectors v and J so that the equation Lv = J describes this situation. Explain what each entry of v and J represents, and how you can use the entries to compute the effective resistance between vertices 1 and 2.
statement_latex:
Consider the following graph, interpreted as a resistor network with all
resistances \emph{R = 1}.

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH307/April_2013/MATH307April2013Section201Q5a.png}
\end{description}

\textbf{(c)} Suppose that by attaching a battery, the voltage at vertex
1 is held at \emph{b\textsubscript{1}} and the voltage at vertex 2 is
held at \emph{b\textsubscript{2}}. Write down vectors \textbf{\emph{v}}
and \emph{\textbf{J}} so that the equation \emph{L\textbf{v}} =
\textbf{\emph{J}} describes this situation. Explain what each entry of
\textbf{\emph{v}} and \textbf{\emph{J}} represents, and how you can use
the entries to compute the effective resistance between vertices 1 and
2.
statement_raw:
Consider the following graph, interpreted as a resistor network with all resistances ''R = 1''.

:[[File:MATH307April2013Section201Q5a.png|300px]]

'''(c)''' Suppose that by attaching a battery, the voltage at vertex 1 is held at ''b<sub>1</sub>'' and the voltage at vertex 2 is held at ''b<sub>2</sub>''. Write down vectors '''''v''''' and '''''J''''' so that the equation ''L'''v''''' = '''''J''''' describes this situation. Explain what each entry of '''''v''''' and '''''J''''' represents, and how you can use the entries to compute the effective resistance between vertices 1 and 2.
